questions.text: A patient present with complaints of sudden and irresistible urges to take an action, this is characteristic of which symptom? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impulse

 

An impulse is characterized by a sudden and irresistible urge to perform an action. In this case, the patient experiences sudden and irresistible urges to take an action, which is a hallmark feature of an impulse.

 

Impulses are often seen in impulse control disorders such as –

 

  • Trichotillomania (an irresistible urge to pull out one's hair)
  • Pyromania (an impulse to set things on fire).

 

In these disorders, the individual experiences a strong, sudden urge to perform a specific action. They may try to resist the urge, but it continues to grow, causing significant discomfort until they finally give in to the impulse and perform the action, which may provide temporary relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hallucination: Is a perception in the absence of an external stimulus, which is not related to the sudden and irresistible urges described in the question.

 

Option C. Delusion: Is a fixed, false belief that is not in keeping with the person's cultural or religious background and is firmly held despite evidence to the contrary. It does not involve sudden, irresistible urges to take an action.

 

Option D. Pseudohallucinations: Are hallucinations that the person recognizes as unreal, which is not the same as the sudden, irresistible urges mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An impulse is characterized by a sudden and irresistible urge to perform an action.

questions.text:
True statement regarding the administration of 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors is/are: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Reduces dihydrotestosterone levels

 

2. Reduces testosterone levels

 

3. Elevates PSA levels

 

4. Decreases PSA levels
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 4

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, are used primarily in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and conditions like male pattern baldness and hirsutism. These medications work by inhibiting the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase, which is responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent androgen.

 

Effects of 5 Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors

 

  1. Reduces Dihydrotestosterone Levels: By inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT, these drugs significantly lower DHT levels in the body. DHT is a key factor in the development and enlargement of the prostate and also contributes to hair loss.
  1. Decreases PSA Levels: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are often reduced as a result of decreased prostate volume and reduced androgenic stimulation of the prostate. PSA is a marker used to screen for and monitor prostate cancer and other prostate-related conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Reduces Testosterone Levels: This statement is incorrect. 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors do not significantly reduce testosterone levels. In fact, due to the reduced conversion to DHT, plasma testosterone levels may remain unchanged or even increase slightly.
  2. Elevates PSA Levels: This statement is incorrect. These drugs typically decrease PSA levels due to reduced androgenic activity in the prostate.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Uses: These inhibitors are used alongside surgery and alpha-1 adrenergic blockers for treating BPH. They are also utilized in managing male pattern baldness and hirsutism.
  • Mechanism of Action: By competitively inhibiting 5 alpha-reductase, they reduce the production of DHT, which is responsible for stimulating prostate growth and hair loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are the competitive inhibitors of the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active dihydroxy testosterone (DHT). This enzyme inhibition results in:

 

 

  • Decreased DHT levels
  • Decreased PSA levels
  • Reduces prostate volume
  • However, plasma testosterone levels remain unchanged or may increase due to non-conversion to DHT.

questions.text: Which of the following is the specific antidote used in the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flumazenil

 

Flumazenil is the drug of choice for treating benzodiazepine overdose. It acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, effectively reversing the effects of benzodiazepines. By administering flumazenil, the respiratory depression and sedation caused by benzodiazepine overdose can be counteracted, making it a crucial antidote in such situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fomepizole is incorrect as it is used in the treatment of methanol toxicity, not benzodiazepine overdose. Fomepizole acts as an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, preventing the metabolism of methanol to its toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Naltrexone is incorrect as it is primarily used for the treatment of alcohol relapse and opioid dependence, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist that helps reduce cravings and prevents the rewarding effects of alcohol and opioids.

 

Option D. Naloxone is incorrect as it is the drug of choice for opioid overdose, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioids, including respiratory depression and sedation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, acting as a competitive antagonist at the GABA-A receptor.

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text: Our physiology is designed to detect harmful substances through the perception of bitterness. Which of the substances listed below is accountable for causing this bitter taste?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaloids

 

Alkaloids binding to receptor à activation of GPCR à IP3/ DAG à ↑intracellular Ca2+ à  secrete ATP which in turn excites sensory afferent fibers à  bitter taste.

 

TASTE

 

 

 

 

Poison, alkaloids are bitter in taste.



Sweet    Sugars (e.g. glucose, sucrose), alcohols (e.g. ethanol), aspartame, aldehydes (like vanillin, cinnamaldehyde)
Sour    Acids (e.g. citric acid, lactic acid), H⁺ ions
Salty    Sodium ions (Na⁺), other metal salts like K⁺ or Li⁺ salts
Bitter    Alkaloids (e.g. quinine, caffeine), poisons, toxins
Umami    Glutamate (e.g. monosodium glutamate - MSG), some nucleotides (e.g. inosinate, guanylate)
 

 

  • Anterior 2/3rd → Chorda Tympani → 7th Nerve
  • Posterior 1/3rd → 9th Nerve
  • Posterior most (pharynx & palate) → 10th Nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Incorrect. Amino acids are not typically responsible for a bitter taste; they are usually associated with the umami taste.

 

Option C. Hydrogen ions: Incorrect. Hydrogen ions are responsible for the sour taste, not bitterness.

 

Option D. Aldehydes: Incorrect. Aldehydes are generally associated with sweet or fruity tastes, not bitterness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaloids are the substances responsible for causing a bitter taste, activating G-protein-coupled receptors and the IP3/DAG pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ and the excitation of sensory afferent fibers.

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

  • Curve A shows linear relationship between PCO2 and Ventilation i.e hypercapnia (↑PCO2) → ↑ Ventilation
  • Curve B shows effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on Ventilation i.e when both Hypercapnia and Hypoxia (↑PCO2 & ↓O2) are present simultaneously but the pH is normal (unchanged)à slope of the curve also changes hence as a result curve becomes Steeper
  • Curve C shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e. when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are present simultaneously → not only the slope of the curve changes but also the Shift of Apneic Point (point denoting PCO2 Levels Below which apnea i.e stoppage of breathing occurs) is seen.
  • Curve D also shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (but in the question pH is Normal 7.35 ) on Ventilation i.e., when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are more severe à the slope of the curve will be more steeper with the Shift of Apneic Point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curve B represents the condition of simultaneous hypoxia and hypercapnia with normal pH, showing a steeper slope in the relationship between PCO2 and ventilation.

choices.text: Dark field

questions.text: Which of the following methods would be the most cost-effective for testing syphilis in a village with limited resources? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark Field

 

Dark field microscopy is the most cost-effective method for diagnosing syphilis, especially in resource-limited settings. It allows direct visualization of the Treponema pallidum spirochetes in samples taken from lesions, such as chancres or condylomata lata. This method is relatively inexpensive and can be performed with minimal laboratory infrastructure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence: Incorrect. While immunofluorescence is a sensitive method for detecting Treponema pallidum, it requires specialized equipment and reagents, making it less cost-effective and impractical for use in resource-limited settings.

 

Option C. Culture: Incorrect. Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, cannot be cultured in artificial media. Therefore, culture is not a viable option for diagnosing syphilis.

 

Treponema can be grown by serial intratesticular passage in rabbit testes.

 

Option D. Simple microscopy: Incorrect. Simple microscopy, such as using a light microscope, is not sufficient for detecting Treponema pallidum because the spirochetes are too thin to be seen without specialized techniques like dark field microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is the most cost-effective method for diagnosing syphilis in resource-limited settings, allowing for direct visualization of Treponema pallidum spirochetes from lesion samples.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: C. diphtheria

questions.text: A child presented with complaint of dysphagia cough, and greyish white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following is causative organism? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C. diphtheria

 

The presentation of dysphagia, cough, and a greyish white membrane over the tonsils is characteristic of diphtheria, which is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

﻿﻿Faucial diphtheria: Toxin elicits and inflammatory response that leads to necrosis of the epithelium and exudate formation leading to formation of pseudomembrane (tough leathery greyish white coat composed of an inner band of fibrin surrounded by neutrophiles, RBCs and bacteria) Bleeds on removal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: Incorrect. Clostridium species are associated with other conditions, such as tetanus and botulism, but not with the formation of a greyish white membrane over the tonsils.

 

Option C. Candida: Incorrect. Candida species can cause oral thrush, which appears as white patches in the mouth and throat, but these do not form a tough pseudomembrane that bleeds upon removal.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is primarily associated with pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media, and does not cause a pseudomembrane on the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, characterized by the formation of a greyish white pseudomembrane over the tonsils, which can bleed upon removal. This is due to the toxin produced by the bacteria, leading to necrosis and exudate formation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During his physical examination, you notice the following discoloration over his face. He is presently being treated with amiodarone, metoprolol, verapamil, lisinopril, and amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is known to cause skin discoloration, which can appear as a bluish or greyish hue, especially on areas exposed to the sun. This effect is due to the drug's deposition in the skin and can occur after prolonged use. Amiodarone-induced skin discoloration (also known as ceruloderma or blue man syndrome) is the most likely cause of the bluish discoloration in this patient's case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. Skin discoloration is not a common side effect of amlodipine.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for various heart conditions, including hypertension and arrhythmias. Metoprolol is not typically associated with skin discoloration.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Another calcium channel blocker used for hypertension, angina, and certain arrhythmias. Like amlodipine, it is not commonly associated with causing skin discoloration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone can cause a characteristic bluish or greyish discoloration of the skin, particularly in sun-exposed areas, due to its deposition in the skin after prolonged use. This side effect is not commonly associated with the other medications listed (amlodipine, metoprolol, and verapamil).

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure


Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as mean arterial pressure (MAP) - intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives oxygen delivery to cerebral tissue. It is the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and the intracranial pressure (ICP), measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). If ICP values are not readily available, central venous pressure (CVP) may be used.

 

Normal CPP lies between 60- and 80-mm Hg,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: Which drug induces the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Norepinephrine

 

The above graph shows fall in the heart rate (reflex bradycardia), with rise in the systolic diastolic and mean arterial pressure. Out of the four drugs above, Norepinephrine can produce these effects by its action of alpha-1 and beta-1 receptors.

 

Stimulation of alpha-1 receptors causes vasoconstriction thus raising the blood pressure. Stimulation of Beta 1 receptors increases the heart rate and stroke volume initially but the increase in mean arterial pressure leads to reflex bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: acts on alpha, beta and Dopamine receptors depending on its concentration. At higher concentration, dopamine increases systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Option B. Epinephrine acts on alpha-1, alpha-2, beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. It increases the SBP and decreases the DBP, thus widened pulse pressure. Consequently, due to cardiac stimulation, heart rate is increased.

 

Option D. Isoproterenol acts on Beta-1, 2 and 3 receptors. It increases the contractility and increases the heart rate due to its beta-1 action. The beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, causing fall in mean arterial pressure and reflex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Norepinephrine is the drug that induces the observed response of increased systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure along with reflex bradycardia. This is due to its potent alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction and initial beta-1 stimulation, followed by the baroreceptor reflex reducing heart rate. Other drugs like dopamine, epinephrine, and isoproterenol have different profiles of action and do not produce this specific combination of effects.

choices.text: B and C
A and B
A, B, C

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text: Cotton swabs are discarded in which bin? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

  • Cotton swabs are discarded in the yellow bin. The yellow bin is designated for infected waste, which includes soiled anatomical waste, chemical liquid, cytotoxic waste, laboratory waste, expired and discarded medicines, and other similar materials. The disposal method for items in the yellow bin typically involves incineration to ensure the complete destruction of potentially hazardous materials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red Bin: Incorrect. The red bin is used for discarding infected plastics such as syringes, gloves, and plastic waste. The disposal method for items in the red bin often involves autoclaving to sterilize the materials before final disposal.

 

Option C. Blue Bin: Incorrect. The blue bin is intended for glassware such as antibiotic vials, metallic implants, and glassware material except cytotoxic. Items in the blue bin are often sent for recycling or treated using plasma pyrolysis or incineration.

 

Option D. Black Bin: Incorrect. The black bin is typically used for general waste, such as kitchen waste, paper, tissues, water bottles, and cans. This waste is generally disposed of through secured landfilling.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure-volume curve? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

The pressure-volume curve represents the relationship between the lung volumes and the transpulmonary pressures. Zero pressure in this context usually refers to the point where the pressure inside the lungs is equal to the atmospheric pressure, indicating a state of no net airflow. This point corresponds to the functional residual capacity (FRC), which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation.

 

  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): It is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. This capacity includes the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and the residual volume (RV). FRC is an important measure because it represents the balance point between the elastic recoil forces of the lungs and the chest wall.

 

 

The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. The normal value is about 2.5 liters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort.

 

Option C: Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in during each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration, during quiet breathing.

 

Option D: Inspiratory reserve volume is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in addition to the tidal volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zero pressure in the pressure-volume curve indicates the functional residual capacity, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation.

questions.text: Examine the provided image and determine the most likely diagnosis from the following conditions: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichobezoar

 

The image shows a trichobezoar, which is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract, usually due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) associated with the psychiatric condition trichotillomania.

 

In trichotillomania, individuals have an irresistible urge to pull out their hair, and sometimes they may also swallow the hair. Over an extended period of time, the ingested hair can accumulate and form a solid mass called a trichobezoar. This hair ball can cause obstruction in the stomach or small intestine, leading to acute abdominal pain that requires surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Splenic rupture is incorrect as the image does not depict a ruptured spleen. A splenic rupture would typically present with intra-abdominal hemorrhage and signs of hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. Pancreatic necrosis is incorrect as the image does not show necrotic pancreatic tissue. Pancreatic necrosis is a severe complication of acute pancreatitis and would not present as a well-defined mass in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Polycystic kidney is incorrect as the image is not depicting the kidneys. Polycystic kidney disease is characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, causing enlargement and progressive loss of renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A trichobezoar is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) in patients with trichotillomania, and can cause acute abdominal pain due to obstruction.

choices.text: They are perceived in the objective space
They are not under the control of the patient

questions.text: All of the following are feature of pseudohallucinations, except: (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They are perceived in the objective space

 

Explanation:

 

True Hallucinations are characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Perception happens without any real object or stimulus triggering it.
  2. They are as vivid and detailed, similar to real perceptions. For example, if a person is experiencing a visual hallucination, the image they see can appear very clear and detailed to them, almost indistinguishable from reality.
  3. Hallucination are perceived in the outer and objective space (external environment).
  4. They are not under the control of the patient. This means the patient cannot start or stop these perceptions at will; they occur spontaneously.

 

Importantly, Pseudohallucinations are perceived in the inner and subjective space, not the outer and objective space. These are perceived as coming from the inner from his/her mind.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They occur without stimulus: This is correct for pseudohallucinations as they happen without any external trigger.

 

Option C. They are vivid: This is also correct for pseudohallucinations. Despite not being real, the perceptions can be very detailed and clear.

 

Option D. They are not under the control of the patient: This is another correct feature of pseudohallucinations. Patients cannot control when these perceptions occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudohallucinations are vivid perceptions without stimulus, occurring in the inner and subjective space, and are not under the control of the patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic alcohol use was admitted with complaints of unsteady gait, difficulty in seeing, and appears confused. Which vitamin is he deficient in? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vit B1

 

The patient's symptoms of unsteady gait (ataxia), difficulty in seeing (ophthalmoplegia), and confusion (global confusion) are characteristic features of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine). The mnemonic "GOA" (Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia) is often used to remember the triad of symptoms associated with this condition.

 

Chronic alcohol use is a common cause of thiamine deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. The treatment involves administering high doses of parenteral thiamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vit B12: Deficiency of Vitamin B12 typically presents with symptoms such as anemia, glossitis, peripheral neuropathy, and in severe cases, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which does not match the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vit C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing, which are not observed in this patient.

 

Option D. Vit B3: Deficiency of Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with the triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. This does not align with the patient's symptoms of ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic GOA), is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) and commonly occurs in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

choices.text: Weakly basic drugs
Weakly acidic drugs

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine will be helpful in the treatment of poisoning due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Weakly acidic drugs

 

Alkalinization of urine is effective in treating overdoses of weakly acidic drugs. By increasing the pH of the urine, it promotes the ionization of these drugs. Ionized drugs are less likely to be reabsorbed in the kidney tubules and are more readily excreted. This principle is particularly applied in cases of aspirin (salicylate) poisoning.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Weakly basic drugs: Urinary alkalinization is not typically used for weakly basic drugs. Basic drugs are more likely to be reabsorbed in an alkaline environment, making this approach counterproductive.

 

Option B. Strong acids: Strong acids are not significantly affected by urinary pH, so alkalinization would not be particularly beneficial.

 

Option C. Strong bases: Similar to strong acids, strong bases are not significantly impacted by changes in urinary pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalinization of urine is an effective strategy to enhance the excretion of weakly acidic drugs by increasing their ionization and reducing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, thus promoting their elimination from the body. This method is particularly useful in cases of poisoning with weak acids, such as aspirin (salicylates).

questions.text: Vessel A has a length of L and diameter of D and vessel B has 2L and 2D. Considering, the flow is laminar through both the cylinders, the flow through B is how many times as much as the flow through A? (INICETMAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 times

 

Flow through B will be 8 times more than the flow through A.

According to Poiseuille Hagen formula,

 

F= AP X π/8 x 1/n x r/L

F= flow

AP = pressure difference between two ends of the tube

П = viscosity

r-radius of the tube

L-length of the tube

Hence flow directly varies to the 4th power of radius and inversely varies to length.

 

Flow through B = (2r)4/2L = 2*2*2*2/ 2 = 16/2= 8 times

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (𝑟4r4) and inversely proportional to the length (𝐿L) of the vessel.

questions.text: In which of the following is atropine contraindicated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute congestive glaucoma

 

The use of atropine is not recommended in cases of acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of increasing intraocular pressure.

 

  • Since atropine is a mydriatic, it may lead to the obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, causing a sudden increase in intraocular pressure.
  • Dim light can also precipitate an attack.
    • Atropine may be indicated as a cycloplegic agent to alleviate pain and prevent synechiae formation in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.
    • In malignant glaucoma, atropine can be the initial management option.
    • In corneal ulcers, atropine is used as an adjuvant therapy, to reduce pain induced by ciliary muscle spasm via its cycloplegic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute anterior uveitis: Atropine is actually beneficial in cases of acute anterior uveitis. It helps to relieve pain by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing the formation of posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and the lens), which can complicate uveitis.

 

Option C. Malignant glaucoma: In malignant glaucoma, atropine might be used as part of the management strategy to try to break the attack by deepening the anterior chamber and pulling the lens-iris diaphragm backward.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: Atropine is used in the treatment of corneal ulcers to provide comfort by relieving the painful ciliary spasm and to prevent synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine should be used cautiously, and is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma due to its potential to exacerbate the condition by further increasing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Which can cause condyloma acuminata? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. HPV 6,11

 

﻿Condyloma accuminata: Genital warts

 

 

﻿﻿HPV types 6 and 11 are the primary causative agents of condyloma acuminata, or genital warts. These types are considered low-risk HPV types because they are not associated with a high risk of cancer but are responsible for the majority of genital warts cases. HPV 6 and 11 can also cause laryngeal warts.

 

Note – HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk HPV types associated with cervical and other anogenital cancers. HPV types 31 and 33 are also considered high-risk and are more commonly associated with precancerous changes and cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV types 6 and 11 are the primary causes of condyloma acuminata (genital warts) and can also cause laryngeal warts. High-risk HPV types like 16, 18, 31, and 33 are associated with cancer and not genital warts.

questions.text: Rh-ve mother had Rh+ve child. This Rh incompatibility is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytotoxic

 

  • Rh incompatibility is an example of Type II hypersensitivity, also known as cytotoxic hypersensitivity. In this type of reaction, the body's immune system produces antibodies (IgG or IgM) against antigens that are part of the cell surface, such as those on red blood cells in the case of Rh incompatibility. When an Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive fetus, her immune system may produce antibodies against the Rh antigen. These antibodies can cross the placenta and attack the fetal red blood cells, leading to hemolytic disease of the newborn.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic (Type I Hypersensitivity): Incorrect. Anaphylactic reactions involve IgE antibodies and occur immediately after exposure to an allergen. Examples include allergic reactions to pollen, insect stings, or certain foods.

 

Option C. Immune Complex Mediated (Type III Hypersensitivity): Incorrect. Type III hypersensitivity involves the formation of immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and tissue damage. Examples include systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Delayed (Type IV Hypersensitivity): Incorrect. Delayed hypersensitivity reactions involve T cells and occur 48-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. Examples include contact dermatitis and the tuberculin skin test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rh incompatibility, where an Rh-negative mother has an Rh-positive child, is an example of Type II (cytotoxic) hypersensitivity reaction, where antibodies produced by the mother attack the fetal red blood cells.
